newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: INTERVIEW - PDL targets global growth.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - PDL targets global growth.

text.p: Electrical and plastic goods manufacturer PDL Holdings Ltd has almost exhausted its growth potential in New Zealand and is focused on international expansion, executive director Neil Archer said on Thursday.

"We've done New Zealand, so to speak. This is our home market and our profitable base, but the only way PDL as a company can do anything to grow is to go offshore," Archer told Reuters in an interview.
PDL, which manufactures a myriad of goods ranging from industrial switchgear to shampoo bottles, already exports to over 40 countries. It is the fourth largest fan heater manufacturer in the world.
Archer said PDL would seek to grow established overseas markets and develop new ones through continued investment in research and development.
"Our expansion has to be to take a group of products, normally industrial-based, that we design and make innovative, and then package and distribute in another market," he said.
"You've got to go there with something that's got more margin in it because of the R&D. The real growth for PDL is in its R&D base."
An example was PDL's invention of a type of safety device known as an RCD (residual current device), which protects domestic and commercial users against electrocution.

"The switch in that is patented worldwide by PDL. It's a very clever switch -- there's only one other company that's come close to us -- so we have a monopoly in the countries where we're selling this particular type of RCD," Archer said.
He said PDL's RCD had gained a 60 percent market share in Britain since its introduction in 1993.
But the test bed for global growth was in Australia, where PDL Industries Australia Pty has just completed its first full year of trading.
"It took us six to seven months to get it profitable, but it had a bottomline profit of $1 million last year and I believe we will have $1.5 million this year," Archer said.

"Australia is a tough market. If we can get the right package that works in Australia and use that as a testing ground, then we're going to use that successful formula and put it into other countries."

Archer said PDL had about five to six percent of the switch and socket market in Australia, but with only two other manufacturers to compete against a share in excess of 20 percent was not unrealistic.

In Asia, the company was changing emphasis away from domestic market sectors to higher margin industrial switchgear, and rationalisation of existing business would be a major focus. But PDL's electronics division was targeting new markets in the United States, Latin America and Asia in the coming year

Archer said the group had not experienced any sales slippage in New Zealand as a result of the sluggish economy and expected to maintain the 10 percent earnings per share growth achieved in 1996/97 in the current financial year.
"I believe there will be some big jumps in PDL's earnings and prospects, but it's finding the right opportunity at the right time.
"All big companies were little companies once -- we're on the way."
PDL reported a NZ$12.53 million net profit for the year to March 31. Archer said the company's bottomline result would tip $13 million this year.
"Our full-year post-tax earnings will be around the $13 million mark," he said.
With wholesaler MasterTrade Group now fully owned by PDL there were no more New Zealand buys on the table, but offshore purchases were likely as the company pursued global growth.
"There will be acquisitions that we need to make in the future offshore," Archer said.
